question: On becoming a UK citizen or permanent resident
options: you will be agreeing to respect the laws, values and traditions of the UK
you can choose which laws and responsibilities you want to accept by ticking on the application form

question: During the 18th century, new ideas about politics, philosophy and science were developed, called 'the Enlightenment'
Who is able to change the Prime Minister during his/her term?
tip: The Prime Minister can be changed if the MPs in the governing party decide to do so, or if he or she wishes to resign. The Prime Minister usually resigns if his or her party loses a General Election.

question: Shakespeare is renowned as the English playwright
Decisions on government policies are made by ______
Who appoints life peers in the House of Lords?
options: The Speaker of the House of Commons
tip: The Prime Minister has the power to nominate peers for their own lifetime, but they are appointed by the monarch.

question: What must you have done in order to vote in elections?
options: Paid income tax in the previous year
Put your name on the electoral register
Registered your identity with the police
tip: To be able to vote in a parliamentary, local or European election, you must have your name on the electoral register. You can register by contacting your local council electoral registration office.

question: Which two of the following are plays by William Shakespeare?
The symbol of Lancaster was a red rose and the symbol of York was a white rose and the war between the House of Lancaster and the House of York was called
The Prime Minister appoints about ______ senior MPs to become ministers in charge of departments
It is ______ to smoke tobacco products in nearly every enclosed public place in the UK
Which was a crucial aerial battle against the Germans?
tip: The Germans waged an air campaign against Britain, but the British resisted with their fighter planes and eventually won the crucial aerial battle against the Germans, called ‘the Battle of Britain’.

question: Who was the first Briton to win the Olympic gold medal in the 10,000 meters?
tip: Mo Farah was the first British runner to win the gold medal in the 10 km.

question: When did Queen Victoria become queen?
tip: In 1837, Queen Victoria became queen of the UK at the age of 18. She reigned until 1901, almost 64 years.

question: The small claims procedure is used for claims of less than ______ in Scotland and Northern Ireland
What is the British Constitution often described as?
tip: The British constitution is not written down in any single document, and therefore it is described as ‘unwritten’. This is mainly because the UK, unlike America or France, has never had a revolution which led permanently to a totally new system of government.

question: In 1846, the Corn Laws prevented the import of cheap grain.
tip: In 1846, the Corn Laws prevented the import of cheap grain.

question: Which TWO are famous horse-racing events?
tip: The Grand National is held at Aintree near Liverpool, and Royal Ascot is a five-day race meeting held in Berkshire.

question: On election day, the polling station or place will be open from
What are the names of TWO famous British film actors?
tip: Tilda Swinton and Colin Firth are two British film actors who have recently won Oscars.

question: British principles and values are based on history and traditions
English kings fought a long war with France was known as
Henry VIII was king of England from 21 April ______
The Corn Laws were repealed in 1846. This had prevented the import of cheap grain
tip: The statement is true.

question: In Northern Ireland a member of your family must complete a voting registration form on your behalf
tip: all those entitled to vote must complete their own registration form

question: Which TWO types of cases are held in County Courts?
tip: County Courts deal with a wide range of civil disputes, including divorce and other family matters, and breaches of contract.

question: How many Olympic gold medals has the Scottish cyclist, Sir Chris Hoy, won?
tip: Sir Chris Hoy (1976–) is a Scottish cyclist who has won six gold and one silver Olympic medals. He has also won 11 world championship titles.

question: Traditionally, what do children do on Mother's Day?
options: Take their mother for a Chinese meal
Take their mother to a park
Take their mother to the cinema

question: Where is St Patrick's Day celebrated on 17th March?
options: Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland

question: Which TWO are facts about King William II of Scotland?
options: He was defeated by King James II of England when the latter tried to take back the crown
He was married to the young daughter of King James II of England, Wales and Ireland
He was the Protestant rule of the Netherlands before he became King William II of Scotland
He was William of Orange before he became King William III of England. Wales and Ireland
tip: James II’s elder daughter, Mary, was married to her cousin William of Orange, the Protestant ruler of the Netherlands. In 1688, important Protestants in England asked William to invade England and proclaim himself king. When William reached England, there was no resistance. James fled to France and William took over the throne, becoming William III in England, Wales and Ireland, and William II of Scotland.

question: The Bronze Age was followed by ______
People don't celebrate Christmas as much as they use to before
Famous British fashion designers are:
The police force is a public service that helps and protects
options: everyone, no matter what their background or where they live

question: What's the age requirement to drink wine with a meal with someone over 18?
tip: 16 year olds can drink wine or beer with a meal in a hotel or restaurant as long as they are with someone over 18.

question: Scotland and Wales remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule
tip: Parts of the west of Britain, including much of what is now Wales, and Scotland, remained free of Anglo-Saxon rule.

question: Snowdonia is a national park in Scotland
tip: Snowdonia is a national park in North Wales

question: The Eden Project is in ______
In 55BC Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain. It was unsuccessful and for nearly ______ years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire
The UN Security Council has five permanent members
tip: The UN Security Council has five permanent members, 15 members in total and the UN has 190 countries as members.

question: By law, radio and television coverage of the political parties must be balanced and so equal time has to be given to rival viewpoints.
tip: The statement is true

question: Civil Servants are political appointees
People are able to buy National Lottery tickets in the UK if they are aged 14 or over.
tip: People under 16 are not allowed to participate in the National Lottery.

question: The Glorious Revolution was called the 'Glorious revolution' because there was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament
tip: The Glorious Revolution was called the 'Glorious revolution' because there was no fighting in England and it guaranteed the power of Parliament

question: It is compulsory to join National Citizen Service programme for 16 and 17 year olds
tip: There are many opportunities for young people to volunteer and receive accreditation which will help them to develop their skills. These include the National Citizen Service programme, which gives 16- and 17-year-olds the opportunity to enjoy outdoor activities, develop their skills and take part in a community project.

question: Rugby originated in ______ in the early 19th century and is very popular in the UK today
Which flower is associated with Wales?
tip: England Rose, Northern Ireland Shamrock, Scotland Thistle, Wales Daffodil.

question: What is the maximum amount for the 'Small Claims Procedure' in England and Wales?
tip: The small claims procedure is an informal way of helping people to settle minor disputes without spending a lot of time and money using a lawyer. This procedure is used for claims of less than £5,000 in England and Wales and £3,000 in Scotland and Northern Ireland.

question: What is an example of the Middle Ages architecture?
options: The White Tower in the Tower of London
tip: In the Middle Ages, great cathedrals and churches were built, many of which still stand today. Examples are the cathedrals in Durham, Lincoln, Canterbury and Salisbury. The White Tower in the Tower of London is an example of a Norman castle keep, built on the orders of William the Conqueror.

question: Reading the Queen speech and opening and closing of Parliament are some ceremonial duties performed by
